generif.text: Data show that granulocyte colony stimulating factor stimulated clone-1, an extracellular matrix glycoprotein, facilitates cell adhesion.

The expression pattern of hGC-1 protein in 173 cases of gastric carcinoma was investigated and a striking correlation was demonstrated between hGC-1 expression and histological type and differentiation of gastric carcinoma.
hGC-1 may be a useful marker for tumor differentiation and progression of human colon carcinoma.
We generated human monoclonal antibodies against 2 potential tumor targets, NGAL and GW112, and we proved their selective expression in cancer colon and not or barely in healthy tissues.
OLFM4 is a robust marker for stem cells in human intestine and marks a subset of colorectal cancer cells.
High serum olfactomedin 4 is associated with gastric cancer.
OLFM4 plays an important role in myeloid leukemia cellular functions

Review critically evaluates recent advances in understanding of the transcriptional regulation of OLFM4 and its upstream signalling pathways with special emphasis on carcinogenesis and outline future perspectives in the field
Results show that cross-talk between estrogen and EGF signaling regulates OLFM-4 expression in human endometrium.
OLFM4 expression and its biological significances in tumor differentiation and progression as well as the contributions of OLFM4 to tumorigenesis (Review)
Olfactomedin 4 expression has been associated with progression of cervical intraepithelial neoplasia and differentiation of cervical cancer.
miR-486 antioncogenic activity may involve the direct targeting and inhibition of OLFM4.
protection of AGT and resistance to nitrosamine-induced genotoxicity critically depends on GSNOR in hepatocytes
The expression of OLFM4 mRNA or protein differed significantly among gastric tumor tissue, matched normal gastric mucosa, and lymph node metastases.
Our results also indicate that OLFM4 is regulated by the Ras-NF-kappaB2 pathway, one of the main oncogenic pathways deregulated in colorectal tumors
Results suggest that S100B, TM4SF3, and OLFM4 overexpression may affect metastatic behavior of tumor cells in Taiwanese colorectal cancer patients.
OLFM4 identifies a subset of human neutrophils.
OLFM4 is overexpressed in active IBD and secreted into mucus. OLFM4 seems to be of functional relevance in IBD as a mucus component, possibly by binding defensins.

depletion of OLFM4 significantly inhibits tumorigenicity of the gastric cancer SGC-7901 and MKN45 cells. Blocking OLFM4 expression can sensitize gastric cancer cells to H2O2 or TNF alpha treatment by increasing caspase-3 dependent apoptosis.
Single nucleotide polymorphism in OLFM4 gene is associated with childhood obesity.
OLFM4 regulates host defense against a broad range of bacteria including Gram-positive Staphylococcus aureus and Gram-negative Escherichia coli in an OLFM4-deficient mouse model.
Reduced expression of olfactomedin 4 and ectopic expression of claudin-18 might be useful markers in the differential diagnosis of serrated polyps.
OLFM4 is a novel candidate tumor-suppressor gene for chromosome 13q and may shed new light on strategies that could be used for the diagnosis, prognosis, and treatment of prostate cancer patients.
Impairment of ERalpha signal-mediated OLFM4 expression promoted the malignant progression of endometrioid adenocarcinoma.
Using a human vaginal epithelial cell line, the expression of mucin 5 subtype B and olfactomedin-4 were down-regulated in response to N9, suggesting these markers could apply to humans
OLM4 expression is increased in the early stages of gastric, colorectal, and pancreatic cancer initiation.
although low OLFM4 expression is not an independent prognostic biomarker, it might indicate worse prognosis for smoking patients with non-small cell lung cancer
High expression of GW112 in colorectal cancer tissues and reduced expression of GRIM-19 in colorectal cancer tissues may be associated with abnormal proliferation of cancer cells.
findings suggest that OLFM4 is not only involved in early stages of gastric carcinogenesis but also a useful prognostic marker for advanced gastric cancer
Patients with an OLFM4 gene expression level above -7.5 were 6 times more likely to develop severe disease, after correction for age at hospitalization and gestational age.
Study demonstrates that epigenetic silencing of OLFM4 enhances gastric cancer cell invasion via activation of FAK signaling.
suppression of OLFM4 expression may be a promising strategy in the development of novel cancer therapeutic drugs
Data show that olfactomedin 4 (OLFM4) is highly expressed in proliferating benign epithelial cells and in some carcinoma cells.
olfactomedin 4 appears to play a critical role in regulating progression of prostate cancer, and has potential as a new biomarker for prostate cancer.

OLFM4 is downregulated by miR-486-5p, which contributes to ovarian cancer tumorigenesis. Conversely, estrogen receptor signaling downregulates miR-486-5p and upregulates OLFM4 expression, slowing the development and progression of ovarian cancer.

OLFM4 has an important role in the regulation of intestinal inflammation and tumorigenesis, and could be a potential therapeutic target for intestinal malignant tumors. Unlike the human colonic epithelium, the mouse colonic epithelium does not express OLFM4, but nevertheless, systemic OLFM4 deletion promotes colon tumorigenesis and that loss from mucosal neutrophils may have a role to play.

Olfactomedin-4 identifies a subpopulation of neutrophils in patients with septic shock, and those with a high percentage of olfactomedin-4+ neutrophils are at higher risk for greater organ failure burden and death. Olfactomedin-4 might serve as a marker of a pathogenic neutrophil subset in patients with septic shock
Olfactomedin 4 is a novel tumor marker for triple-negative breast cancer for predicting and prognosis.
OLFM4 is proved to as a functional target for miR-590.
MiR-103 acts as an oncogene miRNA to promote triple-negative breast cancer cells migration and invasion through targeting OLFM4.
discovered that OLFM4, CD11b, and ITGA2 are proteins that are overexpressed in both primary colon tumors and liver metastasis.  These are colon cancer biomarkers with autoantigenic properties.
these data propose that hCG is not a key regulator of cellular alterations within peripheral blood dendritic cells

Study results suggest that OLFM4, LY6D and S100A7 immunoreactivity are associated with an aggressive phenotype of estrogen receptor (ER)-positive breast carcinoma, and these are potent markers for distant metastasis of ER-positive breast cancer patients.
Results confirm OLFM4 as a tumor suppressor that inhibits cervical cancer metastasis by regulating mTOR signal pathway.

Three of the eight CpG sites in the OLFM4 gene promoter region were hypermethylated in cancerous prostate cells and reduced methylation of eight CpG sites was associated with increased OLFM4 mRNA expression. Findings suggest that OLFM4 plays an important tumor-suppressor role in prostate cancer progression and might be useful as a novel candidate biomarker for prostate cancer.
circulating OLFM4 could be an interesting biomarker of early breast cancer.

Study shows that OLFM4 mRNA level is increased in head and neck squamous cell carcinoma (HNSCC) with low methylation of its promotor region. Increased DNA methylation reduces its expression but does not affect HNSCC prognosis suggesting that OLFM4 DNA methylation occurs prior to carcinogenesis in normal tissue, and its expression would only be involved in tumor initiation but not in progression.
high expression of OLFM4 was involved in chemoresistance and was an independent prognostic factor in pancreatic cancer
Prognostic Significance and Functional Relevance of Olfactomedin 4 in Early-Stage Hepatocellular Carcinoma.
Clinicopathological significance of olfactomedin-4 in extrahepatic bile duct carcinoma.
Olfactomedin 4-Positive Neutrophils Are Upregulated after Hemorrhagic Shock.
Olfactomedin 4 mediation of prostate stem/progenitor-like cell proliferation and differentiation via MYC.
A neutrophil subset defined by intracellular olfactomedin 4 is associated with mortality in sepsis.
Overexpression of Cancer-Associated Stem Cell Gene OLFM4 in the Colonic Epithelium of Patients With Primary Sclerosing Cholangitis.
Super-enhancer-associated long noncoding RNA AC005592.2 promotes tumor progression by regulating OLFM4 in colorectal cancer.
Comparative Analysis of Patient-Matched PDOs Revealed a Reduction in OLFM4-Associated Clusters in Metastatic Lesions in Colorectal Cancer.
Quantitative Proteomic Analysis of Synovial Tissue Reveals That Upregulated OLFM4 Aggravates Inflammation in Rheumatoid Arthritis.
Olfactomedin 4 Is Not a Precise Marker for Human Intestinal Stem Cells, But Is Involved in Intestinal Carcinogenesis.
Olfm4 Is Highly Expressed in HCC Patients and as a Biomarker and Therapeutic Target for HCC.
Olfactomedin 4 regulates migration and proliferation of immortalized non-transformed keratinocytes through modulation of the cell cycle machinery and actin cytoskeleton remodelling.
Increased expression of OLFM4 and lysozyme during necrotizing enterocolitis in neonates: an observational research study.
OLFM4 deficiency delays the progression of colitis to colorectal cancer by abrogating PMN-MDSCs recruitment.
New Insights of OLFM2 and OLFM4 in Gut-Liver Axis and Their Potential Involvement in Nonalcoholic Fatty Liver Disease.
Olfactomedin 4 associates with expression of differentiation markers but not with properties of cancer stemness, EMT nor metastatic spread in colorectal cancer.
Olfactomedin-4-Positive Neutrophils in Neonates: Link to Systemic Inflammation and Bronchopulmonary Dysplasia.
Olfactomedin 4 produces dysplasia but suppresses metastasis of colon cancer.
LRFN5 and OLFM4 as novel potential biomarkers for major depressive disorder: a pilot study.
Blocking OLFM4/galectin-3 axis in placental polymorphonuclear myeloid-derived suppressor cells triggers intestinal inflammation in newborns.

BP.term: positive regulation of substrate adhesion-dependent cell spreading

name: olfactomedin 4
summary: This gene was originally cloned from human myeloblasts and found to be selectively expressed in inflammed colonic epithelium. This gene encodes a member of the olfactomedin family. The encoded protein is an antiapoptotic factor that promotes tumor growth and is an extracellular matrix glycoprotein that facilitates cell adhesion. [provided by RefSeq, Mar 2011].
